p: Studies of the complex of double-stranded polyriboguanylic and polyribocytidylic acids (PolyG:PolyC, Polyguacyl) performed in the 1970sâ€“1980s, showed that the drug had a broad spectrum of antiviral activity and could be effective in the acute phase of viral hepatitis and encephalitis, for the treatment of influenza and rabies [ 61, 66]. However, a number of significant drawbacks, such as the uncertainty of the chemical structure, the lack of homogeneity and, as a result, the unpredictable pharmacokinetics and toxicity of Polyguacyl became a serious obstacle to its clinical use [ 46, 67].
